awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: How People Become Urban
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines three pathways to becoming urban in an expanding city: being born in the city, migrating from a rural area to the city, and living in a formerly rural area that is swallowed up by the expanding borders of the city.  The emphasis is on those who did not migrate but become urban through city expansion as they have been the least studied to date. The questions investigated concern how people understand local belonging, which people and what places are viewed as truly urban and local, who is viewed as part of an in-group or out-group, and who is deemed worthy of local citizenship rights and shared public spaces. Findings will be useful to policy makers and other concerned parties seeking to more effectively promote social inclusion in rapidly transforming cities.

Data collection for this project consists of fieldwork in a large and rapidly growing city. Spatial methods such as mental mapping exercises and city walks complement approximately 140 interviews: 40 interviews with each of the three kinds of city residents and 20 interviews with urban planning experts, drawn from different parts of the city. The interviews investigate how residents subjectively define the spatial and sociocultural boundaries that distinguish the urban and non-urban, the local and non-local, and the deserving and undeserving in their minds. Findings will yield a clearer picture of whether and why a sense of belonging or alienation persists among different types of city residents and how different kinds of city residents view the claims of others to citizenship.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We understand the challenges for assimilation when migrants move from rural to urban areas, but much less is understood about new urban residents produced when city boundaries are at the same time also expanding to include formerly rural areas.  This project examined such a case in rapidly-urbanizing Mainland China, where an estimated 260 million or more migrants achieved urban residence because they were engulfed as rapidly-growing cities have expanded to encompass formerly-rural surrounding areas. Although all migrants share common social integration challenges and affect other group fates in the city, existing scholarship has said little about how these populations are viewed by each other and by native-born residents or about how people define local belonging when city boundaries are constantly in flux.

Much previous scholarly literature has already established that a deep and persistent “rural-urban” divide has existed in the People’s Republic of China since the early days of its founding. But while we know in general that the “urban” tend to stigmatize “rural people,” how do ordinary people determine in their minds who counts as a true “urban” or “rural” person or a “local” versus “non-local” when people are constantly on the move and city boundaries are themselves rapidly changing as they grow? In seeking answers to these questions, this study was among the first to interview three different types of city residents —those produced by urban birth, by rural-to-urban migration, and those urbanized through city expansion—in Chongqing, one of China’s fastest-growing cities. Which people and places within a developing metropolitan area did they view as truly urban and local? Who was viewed as part of an in-group or out-group, and who is deemed worthy of local citizenship rights and shared public spaces?  For our research, we interviewed 110 people in total.

One of our findings confirmed our prior hypothesis. We found that our respondents’ subjective definitions of what people and places counted as truly “rural”/“urban” and “local”/”non-local” often differed from “objective” legal classifications. For instance, many urban-born residents continued to view rural-born migrants to the city as “rural” people (often calling them pejorative names) even after said migrants achieved legal urban citizenship status (via obtaining hukou, or household-registration). Many urban-born residents also continued to view people who have legally become urban citizens through city expansion as still “rural people” as well. Findings like this are socially significant because many studies conducted by scholars and statistical data collected by the government classify people as “rural”/”urban” based upon people’s legal hukou status. My findings suggest that such studies/surveys may not capture the full picture of who actually experiences discrimination and disadvantage. My findings suggest that despite efforts by the government to reduce the salience and importance of place identity through policy reform, place identity remains and important and causally consequential cultural category.

Another of our findings differed from our prior expectations. We had expected that rural-born migrants and former peasants urbanized via urban expansion might express solidarity with one another based upon shared experiences of rural birth and stigmatization by the urban-bor. However, this was not actually the case. We instead discovered that many rural-to-urban migrants expressed envy and disdain towards those urbanized due to city expansion because they often viewed the latter population as having gained urban hukou registration and material compensation for the land they had lost to urban development without making any effort. On the flip side, many of my interviewees who had been urbanized this way envied rural-to-urban migrants who had not lost rights to their land back in their rural hometowns and resentment of these so-called “outsiders” for coming to make money in what had been the former peasants’ own village before its urban redevelopment. This finding holds scholarly significance because the existing literature on China’s urban-rural divide tends to focus so heavily on the schisms between the urban-born and the rural-born that we argue it has comparatively neglected the kinds of social divisions we found between the migrant and non-migrant rural-born new urban citizens. We believe these findings matter for both scholars and policy makers alike because the kinds of sentiments we documented affect individual level life chances as well as group-level outcomes such as social networks, collective efficacy, and social conflict.

Overall, our study affirms the importance attending to ordinary people’s own subjective views rather than reifying and taking for granted legal-official categories or a-priori scholarly assumptions when studying social integration. While this project is a case study on Chongqing, China, we argue that such an approach is likely to become increasingly relevant to other situations across the globe as migration and urbanization accelerates amid climate change. We hope that our findings will help scholars and practitioners better understand the nature and origins of social divisions among different types of urban residents and more effectively promote social inclusion in rapidly-transforming cities.
